text: we didn't experiment having subjects
played Tetris and then looking at their
dreams just as they're following the
street because they all report dreams of
seeing such as pieces falling and musics
report the same sleep onset dreams but
they have no memory of having played the
game those safe things like oh I was
seeing these shapes they were blocks
like rectangles turn down their side I
wish I could remember what they're from
so they're creating Tetris dreams just
the same as everybody else which tells
us that when we're dreaming we're not
using that part of the brain that
remembers exactly how things happen the
main reason people don't remember dreams
is because they fall asleep quickly they
sleep soundly through the night they
wake up with an alarm clock and they
leap out of bed
you can't remember dreams unless you
wake up and you can't recall them unless
you give yourself a chance to lie
quietly and give that dream a chance to
resurface what I tell people who can
never remember their dreams I say drink
three large glasses of water before you
go to bed then you're going to wake up
three or four times during the night and
it turns out you tend to wake up at the
end of REM periods that's just the most
fragile part of your night and you're
most likely to remember them
